item.title: Recent Renegade Con Livestream Announced New World of Darkness Sourcebooks and Retail Release for Kids In Capes
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/tabletop/news/recent-renegade-con-livestream-announced-new-world-of-darkness-sourcebooks-and-retail

Recently, Renegade Game Studios held their summer Renegade Con livestream. In this summer event, the tabletop studio announced several new supplements coming to both World of Darkness and Essence20 RPG lines. They also announced retail pre-orders for Kids in Capes.

The June 2025 Renegade Con Livestream

In a series of livestreams, archived on their official YouTube channel, the June Renegade Con livestream revealed several upcoming tabletop projects and supplements. Some of these livestreams were dedicated to developments in organized play for Axis & Allies and showcased character creation for the latest Essence20 TTRPG, an adaptation of the surreal comedy podcast Welcome to Night Vale.

Notably, the livestream featured two new supplements set to arrive in the World of Darkness franchise. One for Werewolf: The Apocalypse, the other for Vampire: The Masquerade.

The Werewolf supplement, The Moonlit Path, focuses on the spirit world. It introduces players to the secrets of the Umbra and the dangers of crossing into the spirit realm. But with the right know-how, passing into this world may provide new knowledge and skills to combat the machinations of the Wyrm.

Werewolf: The Apocalypse The Moonlit Path is the first major expansion of Gifts in the game.The book contains new Gifts, Talismans, Rites, Loresheets, new threats, and details on three new werewolf septs. The book is available for pre-order now at an MSRP of $50. It is scheduled to be released this October.

For those that want to delve further into urban horror, Vampire: The Masquerade Tattered Facade may have your attention. The supplement focuses on darkening the unlife of Kindred in the setting, introducing elements of Body Horror, Gothic Horror, Folk Horror, and even Cosmic Horror.

The supplement contains more than 25 new Discipline Powers, Rituals, Formulae, Ceremonies and Loresheets. It even contains a new mechanic where Kindred can make a bargain with their inner Beast to master even more Discipline Powers. Tattered Facade is available for pre-order at an MSRP of $50. It is scheduled to be released this November.

As for Essence20, the June Renegade Con livestream announced a new sourcebook for GI Joe, titled Hawk's Personnel Files. This supplement is focused on bringing the Golden Age of GI Joe to the TTRPG, including both player options and pre-generated statblocks of iconic characters. If you have nostalgia for the original Larry Hama comic run or the Sunbow cartoon, the supplement is available for pre-order now. for $50.

Lastly, the livestream announced a retail release for Kids in Capes. It is a superhero spin-off of the award-winning TTRPG Kids on Bikes. After a successful Kickstarter campaign back in May, the TTRPG is now available for pre-order to those who missed out. Both the standard edition and the deluxe edition are available for $39.99 and $49.99 respectively.

In addition, if you pre-order either book, you will receive a set of Kids on Bikes dice at no additional charge.

item.title: Pragmata Preview - Capcom's Next Hit IP?
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/previews/pragmata-preview

I love it when Capcom makes games that aren't from an established franchise. Don't get me wrong, I enjoy Resident Evil, Monster Hunter, and others as much as everyone else, but completely new IPs are also fun.

After several years of silence since its initial reveal, Pragmata was a game shrouded in mystery. A new IP from Capcom is sure to catch anyone's attention, so who wouldn't be curious about it?

We got hands-on gameplay of Pragmata at Summer Game Fest 2025, so join us as we unravel the mystery behind this title.

Two Makes a Team

Although we were able to play through 20 or so minutes of gameplay, the story of Pragmata remains enigmatic. There isn't much in the way of dialogue, other than that we control two characters simultaneously.

One character is this burly man clad in a utilitarian space suit -- his name is Hugh. The other is an android, Diana, that takes the form of a little girl. One might think that this is an escort mission, then, but as it turns out, Diana is quite capable.

Gameplay takes place within this clean, sterile space station. Something's happened, and we're essentially exploring to find a way out. The station is manned by these creepy, humanoid-like robots that are hellbent on taking you out.

Combat largely comprises two components: shooting and hacking. Hugh can shoot various firearms to destroy the robots, and Diana can hack them to make them vulnerable. Just shooting robots without hacking them first means they are near invincible.

Hack and Shoot to Victory

Players have to frantically hack these robots to make them vulnerable. On the upper right portion of the screen, there's a small grid that players use to hack. You have to guide your way to a green node to open a robot's vulnerabilities.

There are also blue nodes that will make them vulnerable for longer, so you have a bit of a high risk, high reward type of situation: hit some (or all) of those blue nodes before the exit, or just go straight for the finish?

Later on in the demo, we pick up an upgrade that unlocks shield nodes on the hacking grid. Hitting those nodes on your path to the seem to make robots take more damage.

The gist of combat is, then, to hack and then shoot. Hacking is succinct and easy enough to handle, though it remains to be seen if the complexity of this system will increase over the course of Pragmata.

Gunplay, by the way, feels pretty tight on controller. If I'm playing a shooter, first-person or, in Pragmata's case, third-person, then I'd prefer a mouse and keyboard. During my demo, I actually forgot I was playing with a controller, so it all felt very natural to control. 

Outside of combat, Hugh explores the station while Diana clings to his back. There are light puzzle and platforming elements, but nothing complex, so it's hard to gauge if puzzles are even the focus of Pragmata.

Pragmata Preview | Final Thoughts

While I did enjoy my time with Pragmata, I couldn't help but wonder how Capcom would continue to keep gameplay feeling fresh. I found three out of what appeared to be four total weapons, so I'm hoping there's more than it appears.

Other than weapons, the hacking might not feel stale after 10 or so hours, but I could see myself finding it a nuisance if Pragmata doesn't constantly introduce new mechanics to keep things fresh.

I'm optimistic, though, because Pragmata is a gorgeous game, and the dynamic between Hugh and Diana has potential to be very heartwarming -- or even tragic. We'll have to find out in 2026, which looks to be a big year for Capcom.

Pragmata was previewed Summer Game Fest.

item.title: Street Fighter 6 Sales Hit 5m Worldwide
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/street-fighter-6-sales-5m

Capcom has announced that Street Fighter 6 sales have topped another major milestone around the world, including sales across all platforms and on both digital and physical platforms.

According to a news post on the official Capcom website, Street Fighter 6 has managed to sell five million copies since launching back in June 2023. The new sales milestone means that the fighting game has picked up another million sales for itself since September last year.

Sales may well have accelerated thanks to the launch of Street Fighter 6 as a Switch 2 launch title. The console, which launched on June 5th, racked up 3.5 million sales within its first four days, making it Nintendo's fastest-selling console around the world.

If you've somehow missed out on Street Fighter 6, it's absolutely far from the sixth installment in the Street Fighter series, but it is the sixth mainline entry. 

The game largely continues the one-on-one fighting game trappings of its predecessors, although it naturally boasts new characters in its roster, as well as new mechanics and a more newcomer-friendly approach (which, incidentally, is one of the things Capcom credits with the new game's popularity).

Street Fighter 6 also features a single-player mode by the name of World Tour, in which players can create their own avatars and explore various environments from both the Street Fighter and Final Fight universes.

Like many modern fighting games, Street Fighter 6 also features rollback netcode, as well as cross-platform play. A host of new characters have also been added to the roster as part of post-launch DLC, many of which are included in the Switch 2's Years 1-2 Fighters Edition package.

Street Fighter 6 is available right now for PC, PlayStation, Xbox Series X|S, and Nintendo Switch 2. You can check out our review of the game here.
